Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(x) = \\int_{0}^{T} e^{At}x(t) dt \\) where A is a constant matrix and x(t) is a function in time. This model explores the transformation of x(t) into z(x) over a period T, focusing on its impact in a linear system described by the differential equation \\( \\dot{x} = Bx \\).

If an intervention changes x(t) at a specific time to \\( x'(t) = Mx(t) \\) where M is another constant matrix, will the resulting \\( z(x) \\) at T be independent of the matrix M?
Explanation: The intervention modifies x(t) to \\( x'(t) = Mx(t) \\), impacting how x(t) is integrated into \\( z(x) \\). Since M alters x(t) throughout the remaining time until T, the resulting \\( z(x) \\) will depend on M due to how the modified function interacts with \\( e^{At} \\) in the integral. Thus, the effect of M is carried through to \\( z(x) \\).
